title: 108_hr3392
content: The "Veterans Claims Procedures Improvement Act of 2003" sets a time limitation on providing necessary information for a claim. If the required information is not received within one year of notification, no benefits will be paid. This does not apply to Government life insurance benefits. The "Veterans Claims Procedures Improvement Act of 2003" amends section 5103 of title 38, United States Code, requiring notifications to be in writing and setting a time limit for submitting information or evidence, with a possible extension for good cause. The Act amends section 5103 of title 38, setting a time limit for submitting evidence. The Secretary can make a decision before the deadline, but if new evidence is received, the decision will be reconsidered. Claimants misled by notification before November 9, 2000, can still submit evidence. In section 5103 of title 38, United States Code, claimants have one year to request a prior decision to be vacated and a new decision issued. The Secretary will do so if the request is made within one year of the enactment of this Act. If no timely request is made, the Secretary is not obligated to locate and reconsider the claim. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF PROCEDURES FOR FILING A NOTICE OF DISAGREEMENT WITH THE BOARD OF VETERANS APPEALS. Section 7105 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to clarify the procedures for initiating appellate review by submitting a written notice of disagreement to the Secretary expressing disagreement with an initial determination. The notice of disagreement is sufficient to initiate appellate review unless the claimant indicates otherwise. If it is unclear whether appellate review is desired or what issues are being appealed, the claimant will be notified and requested to provide clarification in writing. The claimant must provide clarification within a specified time period after being notified of the need for it. Failure to do so will result in the document not being treated as a notice of disagreement. To proceed with the appeal, a written substantive appeal must be submitted after receiving a statement of the case. The appellant is entitled to hearing and representation rights as per the regulations. The appellant is entitled to hearing and representation rights as per regulations. Amendments are made to the filing process for notices of disagreement. Amendments are made to the filing process for notices of disagreement, with changes to the decision-making authority from the agency to the Secretary.
